text:
KIRA HUDSON BANKS: We
think about social change

as something I need to
go out and do for others,

and that oftentimes we skip over
the step of deep self-awareness
of our own positionality.

And so I've seen how that can
impact movements in Ferguson
and the Ferguson uprising.

I think in MeToo we
also have examples

of people doing that
courageous work of being

aware of what they need and
what people who are victims

of oppression deserve
and seeking that

for themselves and
for other folks.

Also, I would say in
my consulting work,

and even in my
research, that there

is real power in doing
our own individual work.

And that through that,
it can be a window

to other aspects of
our identity, which

can lead to connecting with
other systems of oppression

and a catalyst, a real
catalyst, for social movement.

One example of how we can use
one aspect of our identity

to be a window into
others-- and it can actually

be generative for ourselves--
is a research study

that I conducted where
I looked at white women

and tried to understand
how their feminist beliefs

influenced their racial
identity development.

And what I found is that those
who held traditionalist, kind

of mainstream, not including
a race and class analysis

feminist beliefs, that
their racial awareness did

predict having greater
of those beliefs.

But that if they had
inclusive feminist beliefs--

so feminist beliefs that
included an analysis of race
and class--

that that was the how, the
mediator, the catalyst for them

having a more positive
developed racial identity.

So awareness alone is
great but doesn't really

lead us to be
anti-racist and to have

a sense of who we are to
be able to work with others
and move towards action.

And what we found is that
inclusive feminist beliefs
were a catalyst to that.

And that to me
suggests that we need

to think about intersectionality
and, even in that case,

perspectives that aren't our own
and that really being curious

about our own positionality
and the experiences of others

can help us, can further
our own development.

I think raising equity is
a really important concept,

and so important that I
started a podcast that's
called Raising Equity.

That we need to think about how
we raise kids from a young age

to understand systems
of oppression.

And some people are like,
oh, they're too young.
They're innocent.
Let them stay innocent.

But actually, research
shows that they

are aware of racial differences
before they're the age of one.
So they see race, right?

And then in terms of the social
construct of race and all

the ideas and the baggage
that we have about it,

as young as preschool they
start to know those ideas.

And so if they are
seeing race as a baby

and then starting to understand
how we have constructed race--

and some of the stereotypes
and access and barriers

that we have around
this construct--

at preschool, we should
be talking to them

about these ideas, about these
stereotypes, about the system.

And I think that
we need to think

about how to raise kids who
have an awareness of themselves,

of other people, that
have a systems analysis.

And that will allow them to be
able to transform the systems.

They can't transform or
change or be something

different if they're just
on this walkway, this moving

walkway, of the way that
we've always done things.

So we have to
intentionally rear them

in a way that gives
them those tools.
So how do we raise equity?

And so that's what I try
to do in Raising Equity is

to give people frameworks for
how to talk to kids, the work

that we as adults need to do
to be able to do it better,

and then model for them
what it sounds like.

So I do different
episodes with my kids,

with other people's kids
so they can actually

hear what it sounds like to talk
to a kid about racism, sexism,

heterosexism and what
words you might use
to have these conversations.

Parents, teachers, anyone
who is in the life of a kid,

needs to have the
tools to raise equity.
And I think we have them.
We just don't practice them.
And some people don't, actually.

They don't have
the conversations

with other adults, so
they need to work on, OK,

is there knowledge
that I need to get

to know something
about this topic

and then some comfort and
confidence and competence

to be able to engage
in the conversation?
